title: (x) "Catctus thanks" casual serif script - Mister Giggles {Cerilene (self)}
content:
So sorry for the bad image. I’m having a hard time deciding whether this is a font or hand drawn. WTF and Identifont couldn’t seem to match it. Does anyone recognize this?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080322030959im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/cactus.jpg)

Thanks so much for your help :)  
Cerilene :)

 [‹ (x) God of War - Georgia (customised) {Tom C}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080322030959/http:/www.typophile.com/node/18268 "Go to previous forum topic") [An exercise in rendering the beautiful ugly ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080322030959/http:/www.typophile.com/node/18824 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Cerilene Hazel

comments.content: The \_a\_ \_t\_ and \_s\_ seem to be identical so I would lean towards a font. Oh and you can just refer to it as a display font, rather than trying to give it all sorts of catagories.

In my opintion, they are not identical. Look to the top-right of the “s”, and look at the top of the “t”. The “a” seems a little more identical however, but it’s hard to say due to the bad quality of the image if the “a” are the same.

I think it’s not a font. But I guess there are a lot of people here who could help you producing a font out of it ;-)
Sure its a font; The rough bitmap confuses a bit that’s all, no idea which font it is

I agree with Goran. Those differences are not due to image quality — I believe this is hand drawn lettering.

- Mike Yanega

I found it - It’s called Mister Giggles - [http://www.twopeasinabucket.com/shop.asp?product\_id=26428](http://web.archive.org/web/20080322030959/http:/www.twopeasinabucket.com/shop.asp?product_id=26428 "http://www.twopeasinabucket.com/shop.asp?product\_id=26428")

I came across a larger sample on a totally random site today, and they had actually credited the font. When I read the name, I realized... I already own it. \*rolled eyes\*

Thanks for all your help :)

Shows how much I know ;-) Nice catch!

That’s a new one for me to add to the Script Guide.

- Mike Yanega
